We will continue to review our housing subsidy framework so that it is equitable and targeted.

 

     To enhance the living environment, we will invest another $5 billion on HDB estate and flat upgrading. We will expand the Remaking Our Heartland (ROH) programme to cover other towns, beyond Punggol, Yishun, and Dawson. We will complete the Lift Upgrading Programme for all eligible blocks by 2014.  We will also accelerate the Home Improvement Programme (HIP) and Neighbourhood Renewal Programme (NRP).

 

     To meet the needs of an ageing population, we will continue to offer options for senior citizens to monetise their flats.  Some of these will allow the elderly to continue living in their flats in familiar surroundings, among their friends. For example, we will raise the awareness of the newly introduced Lease Buyback Scheme (LBS) among eligible lessees and will consider expanding it to other groups.  We will also step up the construction of Studio Apartments. 

 

My New Singapore

 

     Singapore is fast transforming itself into an exciting and modern metropolis.  We will soon see a new iconic skyline at Marina Bay. The Integrated Resort, Art Park, Business and Financial Centre, and a new waterfront promenade will be progressively completed by 2010. Beyond Marina Bay, we will invest in infrastructure to support new regional growth areas at Jurong Lake District, Kallang Riverside and Paya Lebar. 

 

     Singaporeans can look forward to more leisure and recreation options. We will complete the first phase of the Gardens by the Bay by 2011. We will triple our park connector network to 300 km over the next five-10 years and join it up to form a continuous loop around the island. There will be new scenic walks along our coast, such as the Punggol Coastal Promenade and Labrador Nature and Coastal Walk. There will be new tourism attractions, such as a new River Safari at Mandai, and the Integrated Resorts at Marina Bay and Sentosa.

 

     MND will implement a programme called "My New Singapore" to encourage Singaporeans to rediscover Singapore, through a series of events and activities as well as organised visits to the various new developments and leisure destinations.

 

     We will commence the Concept Plan 2011 exercise this year to draw up long-term plans for Singapore. This comprehensive planning exercise ensures that we will set aside

Column: 63

sufficient land and develop adequate infrastructure to meet the needs of our growing economy and population, whilst maintaining a high standard of living for Singaporeans.

 

     At the same time, we will invest in new efforts to make future growth more sustainable. For example, MND will intensify efforts to promote the adoption of energy efficient technologies in buildings.  MND will also embark on a large-scale solar test-bed within HDB estates.

 

     To support the high quality living environment, MND will ensure that we maintain high food safety standards and supply resilience.  We will continue to strengthen our food supply diversification efforts, such as supporting our companies in investing in agriculture businesses overseas. We will also maintain a high level of vigilance against the introduction of Avian Influenza and other food-borne diseases.

 

Column: 63

 

 

MINISTRY OF THE ENVIRONMENT AND WATER RESOURCES

 

DR YAACOB IBRAHIM

Minister for the Environment and Water Resources

 

     The clean and green environment that Singaporeans enjoy today is the result of careful, coordinated and consistent policies over many years.  Our high-quality living environment will always be our pride and joy.   It is also key to attracting international friends, investors and global talent.

 

     Our vision is to create a Sustainable Singapore where we use our limited resources efficiently and innovatively; pro-actively develop capabilities to deal with emerging challenges; uphold our high quality of life; and foster shared ownership of the environment.

 

Boosting resource efficiency

 

     Our environment will remain an integral part of Singapore's growth.   We will step up efforts to use energy and water more efficiently; to recycle more and waste less.   Doing so will not only see us play our role in the global issue of climate change, but will also help us reduce costs, improve our energy security, and enhance our economic competitiveness. 

 

     The robust and sustainable water supply we have developed will meet our long-term needs. To manage demand, we will sustain our efforts in water conservation through public education and working with community and businesses.

 

High quality living environment

 

     The Active, Beautiful, and Clean (ABC) Waters Programme will transform our reservoirs and waterways into new and aesthetically pleasing community spaces.  We will expand this programme to more water bodies, adding vibrancy to the living environment and enhancing the quality of life.

 

    

Column: 65

We will guard our air quality.  We will control pollution from industry and vehicles to ensure that Singapore's air quality remains among the best in Asia, and comparable with major cities around the world.

 

     To uphold high standards of public health, we will ensure good hygiene at food establishments and step up efforts to keep public premises litter-free.  We will continue with surveillance, research and community engagement efforts to reduce mosquito breeding and lower the incidence of vector-borne diseases.

 

Building environment capabilities

 

     Technology and innovation will help us meet new and emerging environmental challenges.  We will invest in new capabilities to reduce waste and control pollution to add to existing expertise in clean water and energy. As environment and water issues come to the fore on the global agenda, such capabilities can help us position Singapore as a global hub for environment and water solutions, providing economic opportunities and jobs for Singaporeans and helping humanity beyond Singapore.

 

Fostering community action

 

     Building a sustainable living environment requires the support of the community. We will reinforce our close partnerships with the People, Private and Public (3P) sectors to strengthen shared ownership of our environment. We will advance the environmental agenda by reaching out to promote exemplary behaviour and best practices.

 

     Together, we will make Singapore a city that is vibrant and environmentally sustainable - a Singapore which we and future generations will cherish and are proud to call Our Home.

 

Column: 65

 

 

MINISTRY OF TRADE AND INDUSTRY

 

MR LIM HNG KIANG

Minister for Trade and Industry

 

     We will foster economic growth, to help create good jobs and support rising incomes for Singaporeans. We will strengthen the economy to ride out the difficult global economic environment, and gear up to seize new growth opportunities in the post-crisis landscape.  Our vision remains:  Singapore as a leading global city in the heart of Asia, where talent and enterprise can grow and succeed.

 

Weathering the crisis

 

     The world is facing an extraordinary economic crisis, and Singapore has been adversely affected.  We will help viable businesses weather the economic downturn, by facilitating access to financing and alleviating business costs. We will work with industry associations and companies to identify and address key pressure points.

 

     We will ensure that Singapore's economic fundamentals remain sound.  Investors continue to have confidence in Singapore despite the current downturn.  We have the

Column: 67

resources to ride out the global economic crisis and continue to strengthen the capabilities of our companies and improve the skills of our workers to prepare for the upturn.

 

Strengthening our companies, investing in our workers

 

     We have a diversified economy. Through the years, companies based in Singapore have moved up the value chain through innovation and upgrading, and are able to generate new products and services. We have seeded new growth areas such as Biomedical Sciences, Clean Technology, Interactive Digital Media, and Water and Environment Technologies.

 

     SPRING will work with SMEs to raise their productivity by deepening  their corporate capabilities in branding, design, service excellence, customer-centric initiatives and technological innovation. IE Singapore will help companies strengthen their export capabilities.  EDB will facilitate companies to conduct more R&D, develop new capabilities, and test new products and services here in Singapore. A*STAR will strengthen the connections between our research organisations and industry, so that our companies can leverage on the latest technologies to create new products and services.

 

     We will invest even more in our workers. As companies respond to new demands, we will re-skill our workers with the necessary proficiencies and skills to meet the talent demands of our enterprises.

 

Expanding our markets, extending our networks

 

     We will continue to reach out to new markets overseas, and deepen our presence in existing markets.

 

     We remain committed to free and open trade, as protectionist measures hurt consumers and businesses and hinder economic recovery and growth. We have intensified efforts toward an ASEAN Economic Community that will open up opportunities to businesses and consumers as trade, services, and investment flows increase in our region. Through ASEAN, APEC, and other regional fora, we will continue working to enhance regional economic integration, deepen economic linkages, and keep trade and investments flowing across borders.

 

     We will continue to build on our strong network of Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) to enhance existing linkages as well as develop new ones.  We will step up efforts to assist companies to utilise these FTAs to enhance their access to overseas markets.

 

     We will step up efforts to help our companies expand in key markets such as China, India, Southeast Asia, and the Middle East.  We will enhance efforts to engage and understand emerging markets with potential, such as in Latin America and Eastern Europe.

 

Home for business, home for talent

 

     Even in the midst of the global crisis, Singapore remains open for business.  We offer a first-class business environment and infrastructure, and a skilled and flexible workforce.  We remain committed to ensuring that Singapore is an attractive home for business and talent.

 

    

Column: 69

We will continue to review our regulations and remove red tape, making it easier, faster and cheaper for businesses to operate in Singapore. The Competition Commission of Singapore will continue to promote competitive markets, which will spur innovation and efficiency in our businesses.

 

     We will continue to invest in our physical infrastructure. JTC Corporation will master-plan sector-specific industrial parks to develop dedicated infrastructure ahead of time to support the growth of our economic clusters. Energy Market Authority will enhance Singapore’s energy security by diversifying into liquefied natural gas; and promote greater retail contestability in our electricity market. 

 

     We will continue to build Singapore as a destination of choice. In the next few years, Singapore's tourism landscape will be enhanced with a stream of new offerings, including the Integrated Resorts, Gardens by the Bay and the River Safari. These offerings will engage local residents and foreign visitors with fresh, authentic and unique experiences. 

 

     We will embark on a more concerted effort to deepen the capabilities of our companies so that they can compete on the global stage. At the same time, we will encourage more foreign MNCs and high-growth companies to anchor their key functions here, and to work in partnership with Singapore-based companies so that they can be part of the Asian growth story.

 

     Singapore will be a home for talent - a city that welcomes global talents and nurtures home-grown talents to maximise their full potential. Singapore will be the location of choice for scientists, entrepreneurs, professionals and creative individuals - where they exchange ideas, build their careers and homes, and pursue their aspirations.

 

Column: 69

 

 

MINISTRY OF TRANSPORT

 

MR RAYMOND LIM SIANG KEAT

Minister for Transport

 

     We will help Singapore to be a vibrant, global city by strengthening our position as a leading transport and logistics hub. We will also help to create an attractive living environment and meet the diverse transport needs of our people by providing Singaporeans with an integrated, efficient, cost-effective, and environmentally sustainable urban transport system.

 

Singapore as a leading maritime city

 

     We will continue to enhance Singapore's position as a leading maritime city, both as a top hub port, and as a centre for the full range of maritime businesses. 

 

     Singapore has been the world’s busiest container port since 2005.  We will continue to make timely investments in our port infrastructure to prepare for an even busier port in the future.  Despite the current economic downturn, the expansion of Pasir Panjang Terminal is proceeding without delay.   Plans to construct a new port operations control centre and to deepen our port approaches are also underway.  Singapore-based businesses will continue to enjoy the competitive advantage conferred by the superior international connectivity and service levels of our port. 

 

    

Column: 71

As an international centre for maritime businesses, Singapore also has a vibrant ecosystem of ship owners and operators, ship managers and brokers, shipping banks, maritime insurers and lawyers, and more.  We will continue our industry development efforts and grow Singapore into an even more vibrant focal point where the international maritime community congregates to network and exchange ideas.

 

Keeping Changi ahead

 

     Although the current economic downturn has badly affected the global aviation industry, we will continue to enhance the competitiveness and dynamism of Singapore as an aviation hub so that we can emerge stronger from this crisis and extend our lead over our competitors.

 

     The corporatisation of Changi Airport will enable us to make a strategic shift from a position of strength. This will ensure that Changi has the flexibility to respond quickly to changes in the industry and that passengers will continue to enjoy the superior Changi Experience that is associated with the airport.  The corporate entity will be better able to attract and retain talent, and to pursue overseas ventures and investment opportunities more aggressively.  In this way, Changi will continue to enhance Singapore's position as an aviation hub in the years ahead.

 

     We will continue to enhance our air connectivity through a liberal aviation policy so that both Singapore and foreign carriers can expand their network and services at Changi. To tap the potential of the Southeast Asia market, we will push for further air services liberalisation within ASEAN and between ASEAN and her key regional partners such as China and India. 

 

     The region has seen an impressive growth of Low Cost Carriers (LCC). We will continue to nurture and help these carriers grow their operations out of Changi Airport, to strengthen our hub connectivity.

 

Providing a people-centred land transport system

 

     In 2008, we launched the Land Transport Masterplan to guide the development of land transport over the next 10 to 15 years.

 

     Many of the proposals in the Masterplan represent significant changes. They require close partnership with many stakeholders, and heavy investment on the part of the Government, before they can be realised. Despite the current difficult economic conditions, we will continue to take a long-term view, to provide a high-quality and affordable land transport system that meets the diverse needs of our people and contributes to making Singapore a liveable, vibrant global city.

 

     The majority of Singaporeans today make use of public transport as their principal mode of travel.  The role of public transport would have to become even more important if we are to meet the transport needs of a growing population and economy within our land constraints while being sensitive to environmental concerns. One strategic thrust of our land transport policy is therefore to develop a public transport system that is an attractive and viable alternative to the car.

 

    

Column: 73

In the year since the Masterplan was released, we have made several improvements to the public transport system including higher bus and train frequencies and faster journey times through bus priority measures. We will continue to roll out new initiatives to further improve efficiency and service levels, guided by the central idea of adopting a people-centred approach.

 

     Over the next few years, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) will take on the role of a central bus network planner, so that the entire transport infrastructure - bus routes, rail corridors and roads - can be planned as a whole. We will improve the integration of bus and rail systems, so that travel on the public transport system is more seamless. We will continue to invest in our rail network, to serve new areas and further reduce journey times. We will drive service improvements by introducing greater contestability in the bus and rail industry, building more infrastructure and raising service quality standards.  In all these initiatives, the overarching principle is to put the commuter at the centre - to focus on commuters’ key priorities such as speed, reliability, convenience, and affordability. 

 

     We will continue to invest in expanding the road network, and make use of technology to optimise the capacity of our roads. To ensure that traffic remains smooth, we will continue to refine the various car ownership and usage restraint measures, to encourage Singaporeans to reduce their reliance on cars, and to consider public transport as a choice mode of travel.

 

     We will continue to improve the accessibility and inclusiveness of our transport system, to cater to increasingly diverse needs. Our MRT stations and public buses will be elderly- and disabled-friendly. Pedestrian walkways and bus stops will also be upgraded to make it easier for the less-mobile to move around. To improve the pedestrian walking experience, we will have more sheltered walkways as well as more extensive underground pedestrian networks and better connectivity of our transport nodes to nearby buildings, especially in the city.  As cycling becomes an increasingly popular mode of transport, we will facilitate cycling, including building more cycling paths where possible.

 

     Our land transport policies will continue to be sensitive to environmental considerations.  We will strive for cost-effective measures for cleaner and greener transport, and do our part in reducing air pollutants as well as greenhouse gas emissions. 

Column: 73

 

 

PRIME MINISTER'S OFFICE (MINISTERIAL COMMITTEE ON AGEING)

 

MR LIM BOON HENG

Minister (Prime Minister's Office) and Minister-in-charge of Ageing Issues

 

     Established in March 2007, the Ministerial Committee on Ageing is committed to achieving the vision of "Successful Ageing for Singapore".  The Committee takes a whole-of-Government approach to pursue the strategic thrusts of enhancing financial security and employability; enabling ageing-in-place; providing holistic and affordable healthcare and eldercare; and promoting active ageing.

 

     Through these efforts, Singaporeans should have the fullest opportunity to lead happy, healthy and active lives as they age.  Families should remain the bedrock of care and support for our elders.  We will forge an inclusive society for young and old.

 

Column: 75

Enhancing employability and financial security

 

     As we live longer, we also need to work longer to fund our expenses.  The Ministry of Manpower, with its tripartite partners, will press on to implement re-employment legislation in 2012.  Re-employment will be complemented by continuous education and training, and schemes to promote age-friendly workplaces and flexible work practices.  Low-income older workers also enjoy added incentives to work through the Workfare Income Supplement Scheme.

 

     To help Singaporeans save for old age, the CPF has undergone a series of reforms.  From 2013, the CPF LIFE scheme will be implemented to provide CPF members with a regular stream of income for the rest of their lives.  We will raise awareness of the recently introduced Lease Buyback Scheme to enable lower-income elderly release equity from their HDB housing.

 

Enabling ageing-in-place

 

     Our physical environment should be accessible and safe for all Singaporeans, even those who are less mobile.  All HDB housing estates will be barrier-free by 2011.  The Lift Upgrading Programme, which provides lift access to all floors of eligible HDB blocks, will be completed by 2014.  A $60 million programme to make pedestrian walkways, access to MRT stations, taxi and bus shelters and public roads, barrier-free will be completed by 2010.

 

     Singaporeans will also have more choices to live in housing which is appropriate to their life stage and finances.  HDB will build more studio apartments and smaller flats to facilitate right-sizing options.  Over the next two years, about 2,000 units of Studio Apartments, 2- and 3-room flats will be launched each year.  We will also look into different models of housing and services to facilitate ageing-in-place.

 

Providing holistic and affordable healthcare and eldercare

 

     The Government is committed to a substantial expansion of the healthcare sector.  We will boost capabilities to treat and manage chronic diseases including dementia.  More intermediate and long-term care services such as community hospitals, nursing homes, day care and home-help services will be introduced.  We will develop more services and support schemes for family members and caregivers.

 

     All around the world, countries are grappling with how to finance long-term care.  Our existing 3Ms framework for acute hospitalisation – Medisave, Medishield and Medifund – provides a good basis from which to develop sustainable solutions.  We already have the basic long-term care insurance (Eldershield) and safety net (Medifund Silver) components in place.  The Government will study how to enhance these two components and help Singaporeans set aside sufficient savings for their care needs. 

 

Promoting active ageing

 

     The Government is committed to promoting a positive and active mindset towards ageing.  The Council for Third Age, funded by the Ministry of Community Development,

Column: 77

Youth and Sports, will champion active ageing and promote new programmes for seniors.  We are studying how the Wellness Programme, currently piloted in 12 constituencies to help older residents better manage their health and be socially connected, can be introduced to other constituencies.

 

     Singapore is well placed to seize the economic and social opportunities that come with ageing.  Asia is the fastest ageing region in the world.  We will develop Singapore as a thriving business and research centre on ageing. 

Column: 77

 

 

PRIME MINISTER'S OFFICE (MONETARY AUTHORITY OF SINGAPORE)

 

MR GOH CHOK TONG

Senior Minister and Chairman, MAS

 

     The past year has witnessed a period of extraordinary stress in the global financial system and a deep economic recession worldwide.  Although the global financial condition has stabilised, the situation is fragile and we need to remain vigilant.

 

     The Singapore economy weakened considerably from the second half of 2008.  Meanwhile, headline inflation came down significantly from its peak in mid-2008.  MAS' monetary policy objective is sustainable, non-inflationary economic growth over the medium term.  This will underpin confidence in the Singapore Dollar.  In light of increased uncertainties in the economic environment, MAS will bolster our surveillance and analytical framework to incorporate more real-time information and enhance our assessment of industry and corporate level developments to complement macroeconomic projections.  We have also strengthened our ability to ensure adequate market liquidity in Singapore's banking system even during periods of heightened volatility and general risk aversion in global financial markets.

 

     The financial crisis has highlighted the importance of prudent supervision of financial activities.  Although not directly affected, financial institutions (FIs) in Singapore can be susceptible to risks of contagion from developments elsewhere and to second round effects of the economic slowdown.  MAS will continue to work with FIs to strengthen their risk management systems and processes.  We will embark on thematic reviews and stress tests to assess the risks of FIs, and fine-tune measures for FIs to mitigate financial stresses such as increasing prudential buffers.  We will also intensify our ongoing dialogues with the home regulators of foreign FIs which operate here, so as to share information about the safety and soundness of these institutions.  Furthermore, we will enhance our crisis management capabilities to minimise fallout in the event of FI failure.

 

     To complement the supervision of individual FIs, MAS will step up our macro-prudential surveillance.  This entails enhancing our gathering of market intelligence, and analysing broader systemic risks including the mechanisms through which risks in one segment of our financial system can be transmitted to another.

 

     Concurrently, MAS will position Singapore's financial centre to emerge stronger post-crisis.  MAS will study the revisions being proposed internationally to existing capital adequacy frameworks, and make appropriate amendments to our rules.  In addition, we will finalise enhancements to the regulatory framework for the sale and marketing of investment products.  This is to promote more effective disclosure and fair-dealing in the

Column: 79

sales and advisory process.  We will continue to work with our stakeholders to strengthen the corporate governance of listed companies and to deliver relevant financial education programmes under MoneySENSE.

 

     Emerging stronger from the crisis entails efforts to develop our financial centre as well.  Singapore's sound regulatory framework and well-respected judicial system will enhance our proposition as a trusted centre for asset management and risk management.  Whilst growth momentum may moderate in the next few years, the Asian growth story remains intact over the longer term and Asia will continue to be an important region for asset management opportunities.  Next, the risk appetite of global banks will remain muted for some time.  Companies in Asia are therefore turning to domestic loan and regional capital markets for their funding needs.  We can ride on this by positioning Singapore as a leading international marketplace for fund-raising, risk management and trading of local currency securities.  MAS will continue to support the development of market infrastructure and products that are relevant to players based in Asia.  Finally, we will work on initiatives to encourage FIs to continue investing in manpower retention and talent development, so as to ready themselves for the upturn. 

 

Column: 79

 

 

PRIME MINISTER'S OFFICE (NATIONAL POPULATION SECRETARIAT)

 

MR WONG KAN SENG

Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs

 

     Singapore needs a sustainable, connected and integrated population in order to survive and thrive. We must press on with our efforts to build a strong core of committed and dedicated citizens, who will ride through these trying times together, and emerge as a more resilient, cohesive and integrated society.

 

First priority to citizens

 

     Citizens will always remain the Government's first priority, and citizen interests will always be accorded a higher priority over those of Permanent Residents and foreigners.

 

     The Marriage and Parenthood Package was enhanced in August 2008 in order to provide a more pro-family environment in terms of financial, work-life and childcare support in Singapore. It is premature to assess if the package has worked in encouraging couples to marry and have more children. We will continue to monitor its effectiveness. Although some couples may delay their family plans in this current economic crisis, we hope that they will not do so for too long.

 

     We will also continue to engage the estimated 180,000 Singaporeans overseas even in these hard times. They are a part of our Singaporean family and we must not neglect them. We will continue to extend the outreach of our programmes to engage a wider spectrum of Overseas Singaporeans, and strengthen their connection with Singapore.

 

An integrated community

 

     Even as we do all we can to help Singaporeans in this economic crisis, we must also re-position ourselves to ensure that we are ready to ride on the next wave of economic growth. We can only do so if all Singaporeans stand united as one.

 

    

Column: 81

All Singaporeans, native or new, have a significant role to play in forging an integrated community, by strengthening community and social bonds in Singapore. The National Integration Council will harness the collective efforts from the private, people and public sectors, and encourage more ground-up initiatives to integrate Singaporeans where they live, in the workplace, in schools, and through social and community involvement. We will also expand efforts to help those who are interested to sink roots and set up home in Singapore through their naturalisation and integration journey, including making information available to them online at www.home-in-singapore.sg. We will also reach out to them and facilitate their becoming active members of the Singapore community.

 

The Singapore Promise

 

     Singaporeans have contributed much to Singapore's transformation over the past 40 years. Our forefathers and, more recently, the new immigrants have come here because of the promise and potential of Singapore: the promise that any individual who has made Singapore home could realise his or her aspirations, and the promise that Singapore will be a good home for them. It is through our ability to understand, appreciate and respect one another that we can have a Singapore for Singaporeans. All of us have a duty today to contribute to and deliver the "Singapore Promise" for ourselves and our descendants.

 

Column: 81

 

 

PRIME MINISTER'S OFFICE (NATIONAL RESEARCH FOUNDATION)

 

MR LEE HSIEN LOONG

Prime Minister

 

     The mission of the National Research Foundation (NRF) is to help transform Singapore into a knowledge-intensive, innovative and entrepreneurial economy. The NRF seeks to deepen Singapore's R&D capabilities and capacity, encourage greater innovation and the growth of technology-based enterprises in Singapore.  This will help Singapore remain competitive and offer opportunities to our people to better their living.

 

Developing excellence in use-inspired research

 

     Great scientific breakthroughs are often not made by a single brilliant researcher working in isolation, but by teams of scientists working across disciplines.  Recognising this trend, the NRF seeks to develop research excellence in multi-disciplinary areas in our local universities, by jointly establishing with MOE, a small number of world class Research Centres of Excellence (RCEs). 

 

     Four RCEs have been approved so far.  They are the Centre of Quantum Technologies, Cancer Science Institute of Singapore and the Mechanobiology RCE at the NUS; and the Earth Observatory of Singapore at NTU.   When fully operational, they will train some 580 PhD students and post-doctoral fellows, adding significantly to the local talent pool in multi-disciplinary research.  They will contribute to generating knowledge and innovation that could be commercialised. 

 

    

Column: 83

Under the NRF Research Fellowship programmes, we will attract and root top research talent in Singapore by providing brilliant young scientists the opportunity to direct independent research teams. These NRF Research Fellows will be encouraged to take up appointments at the local universities and offered tenure-track positions.  They will provide not just the resources and talent to generate breakthrough ideas, but help create an environment and culture for our people to do the same.

 

     The NRF is establishing an international Campus for Research Excellence And Technological Enterprise (CREATE), to bring together in one physical location, research centres from some of the world’s top research universities.  The concentration of diverse talents doing cutting edge research in CREATE would act as a magnet for attracting more research talent locally and from all over the world, making Singapore perhaps the first R&D hub that congregates the best of research talent from diverse cultures and backgrounds.

 

     We will continue to invest in strategic research areas where Singapore has a competitive edge to gain a leadership position or create new industries. The Biomedical Sciences (BMS) Translational and Clinical Research programme (BMS-TCR) has a clear intent to translate basic research into treatments for patients.

 

     The Environment and Water Technologies (EWT) Programme seeks to develop a new water industry supported by strong R&D, as well as position Singapore as a Clean Energy Hub.

 

     The Interactive and Digital Media (IDM) Programme leverages on Singapore's strong foundation in ICT and education to create new innovative niches with a focus on games and edutainment.

 

Strengthening research, growing innovation and enterprise

 

     Innovation is key to sustainable economic growth, and hi-tech start-ups are responsible for most breakthrough innovations, job and wealth creation.  The NRF has developed the National Framework of Innovation and Entrepreneurship (NFIE).  Going forward, this will help Singapore better boost innovation and academic entrepreneurship to translate the treasure trove of knowledge from our tertiary and research institutions into applications and products.

 

     All of NRF's programmes are directed at strengthening research, growing innovation and enterprise.  Working with other agencies, the NRF seeks to create a self-reinforcing innovation eco-system in the country, which will provide the basis for sustainable economic growth into the future.

Column: 83

 

 

NATIONAL SECURITY COORDINATION SECRETARIAT

 

PROF. S. JAYAKUMAR

Senior Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security

 

     It is during times when no terror has struck that the danger of fatigue and complacency increases.  Recent terror attacks in India and Pakistan, and arrests in the UK,

Column: 85

remind us that the threat from trans-national terrorism persists.  Continued vigilance and resilience are essential if we are to achieve safety and security for Singapore and Singaporeans.  In Singapore, our security agencies have remained vigilant.  Although we have made good progress, we cannot afford to be complacent.  A well co-ordinated Government structure to deal with the threat of trans-national terrorism can only be effective with the participation of all Singaporeans.  Our national security must be a collective effort of the Government, the people of Singapore and the business community.  The National Security Coordination Secretariat (NSCS) will therefore continue to organise and coordinate national security awareness programmes, such as education and outreach activities to engage all stakeholders.  While aiming for the best outcomes, we must be prepared for the worst.

 

Whole-of-Government coordination

 

     Trans-national terrorism is a complex and constantly evolving threat.  To deal with it effectively demands a whole-of-Government approach that emphasises coordination and collaboration.  This approach leverages on the resources and capabilities of individual Ministries and Government agencies, creating synergies without placing an undue burden on budget and manpower.

 

Leveraging on technology  

 

     Terrorists are becoming increasingly sophisticated in their methods.  We will correspondingly have to harness advanced technologies to deter, detect, protect and respond.  Given Singapore's limited resources, technology is an effective force multiplier.  Therefore, a National Security Engineering Centre (NSEC) has been created within the Defence Science Technology Agency to support the national security effort.  A national security technology roadmap has also been developed to guide the exploitation and development of technology.

 

Horizon scanning and risk management  

 

     NSCS has developed a prototype Risk Assessment and Horizon Scanning (RAHS) capability.  This is being deployed across various domains and has raised Singapore's strategic anticipation capability.  The RAHS system will also facilitate inter-agency collaboration and horizontal communication among the various security agencies, reflecting the whole-of-Government approach that underpins that national security effort in Singapore.

 

Column: 85

 

 

PRIME MINISTER'S OFFICE (PUBLIC SERVICE DIVISION)

 

MR TEO CHEE HEAN

Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence

 

     The Public Service has contributed to Singapore's hard-won reputation as a vibrant, safe and attractive country to live, work and play in. Maintaining this reputation requires continuing efforts to relentlessly pursue improvements, guided by the Public Service’s core values of Integrity, Service and Excellence.

 

    

Column: 87

Singapore is now experiencing its deepest recession since independence.  The Public Service is critically aware that the immediate measures needed to mitigate the effects of the downturn on Singapore and Singaporeans have to be carried out effectively and with empathy.

 

     At the same time, the Public Service will continue to keep its eye to the future, to anticipate and manage the rapid changes in Singapore’s external environment, and to seek emerging opportunities as the global economic situation evolves. The Public Service will develop our human resources, enhance our policy making capability, and improve our service delivery to the public.

 

Investing in talent to improve Public Service

 

     The Public Service is stepping up efforts to bring in capable and committed people to raise the quality of public services and to build up new capacity. The current recession has provided us with good opportunities to do so.

 

     We need bold and visionary Public Service leaders who can operate as one Government, and are adaptable to changing environments. They must also serve the people of Singapore with humility, integrity and empathy. We will therefore enhance the quality of Public Service leaders by giving them varying and challenging job assignments, including overseas postings, cross-agency projects and attachments to non-Government and community organisations. The Civil Service College will also enhance its existing slate of leadership training programmes.

 

     As a responsible employer, the public sector will provide our employees with opportunities to acquire new skills and competencies to take on more challenging work. We will continue with our efforts to re-design jobs, especially for our support staff, and equip them with employable skills. 

 

     To address Singapore's ageing society and the resultant shifts in the manpower landscape, the Government has committed to enacting re-employment legislation. The Public Service plans to take the lead by introducing its re-employment policy ahead of national legislation.

 

Anticipating, embracing and executing change

 

     The Public Service needs to constantly think ahead and improve.  This is only sustainable if every officer is involved.

 

     The PS21 (Public Service for the 21st Century) movement was launched 14 years ago. Since then, many new officers have joined the Public Service. We will work with all public sector agencies to re-energise the PS21 movement so that public officers understand the need to embrace change, and are equipped with the mindset and tools to effect change.

 

Being responsive in serving the public

 

     As we cultivate a Public Service that is more open to change, it is equally important to inculcate a stronger service ethos across all levels in the Public Service.  Although we have done well in international surveys, public expectations of service standards have increased, and issues are more complex. 

 

    

Column: 89

It is important for the Public Service to keep in close touch with ground concerns in order to formulate policies that are relevant to the needs of all Singaporeans. Where possible, public officers are strongly encouraged to seek the views of constituents who will be affected by the policies. Under our Community Attachment Programmes, senior officers are attached to grassroots organisations like Resident Committees and Community Development Councils (CDCs), while the Community Involvement Programme provides opportunities for officers to work directly with the less privileged in our society. Through such programmes, our officers gain deeper insights into the needs and concerns of Singaporeans, and will be better able to draw on their first-hand experiences to develop effective policies for fellow Singaporeans.

 

     We will continue to work with Quality Service Managers to improve the implementation of the 'No Wrong Door' policy. We are also working with the Civil Service College to improve training for public officers to develop greater empathy for issues faced by the public. At the same time, the Public Service will also recognise members of the public who are 'role model customers' so that the Public Service and the public it serves can work in partnership to improve service quality and standards.

 

Looking forward and seizing opportunities

 

     As the Public Service braces itself to help Singaporeans deal with a recession, the duration of which is still uncertain, we will not lose sight of the opportunities that will arise, both during and after the current crisis. We will continue to improve our capacity to serve the public by recruiting, training and developing public officers, so that the Public Service can continue to work with Singaporeans to build our nation's future.
